conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to determine the path the liquid from each container (A, B, C, and D) will take as it flows through the baffles and into which container (E, F, or G) it will ultimately flow.
Container A is green, container B is pink, container C is yellow, and container D is blue.
Container E is brown, container F is pink, and container G is blue.
There are slanted barriers of different colors: brown, purple, yellow, and blue.

premise: Stream A strikes the brown slanted barrier and is deflected to the right.
conclusion: Liquid from A flows into container E.

premise: Stream B hits the purple slanted barrier and is deflected to the left.
conclusion: Liquid from B flows into container F.

premise: Stream C and D impact the yellow baffle and turn left.
conclusion: Liquid from C and D mix and flow into container F.

premise: Liquid from A and B mix up then encounter the blue baffle, turn right and meet with the mixture of Stream C and D.
conclusion: Most mixture of A, B, C, and D ends in container F.

premise: Stream A strikes the brown slanted barrier and is deflected to the right.
conclusion: A thin stream of mixture from A ends in container E.

premise: Stream B hits the purple slanted barrier and is deflected to the left.
conclusion: No stream ends in container G.

premise: Liquid from A flows into container E; liquid from B and C flows into container F; liquid from D flows into container G.
conclusion: Final Answer: Most mixture of A, B, C, and D end in container F; a thin stream of mixture from A ends in container E; no stream ends in container G.
